When I rented this, I was excitedly expecting a modern take on the classic battle between technology and mythic beasts, similar to "Reign of Fire". Although not what I initially hoped, I ended up enjoying a thrilling "monster hunts heroes in a remote building" movie.

Featuring a captivating script, catchy music, impressive effects, engaging plot, and exceptional acting. I was pleasantly surprised and would rate it highly.

This movie is absolutely great. Strong story, excellent directing, and outstanding acting. The frequent product placements, while noticeable, did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the movie. In fact, they provided a unique insight into the world of product integration in film. This movie is a treat for any moviegoer, well worth the investment of your time.

I'm a big fan of the true crime genre, and I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It was a unique take on the story of Dahmer, featuring an excellent soundtrack that added to the overall experience. The film provided a deep look into what made Dahmer tick, and also explored the lives of his victims in a respectful manner. The movie effectively portrayed the complex nature of Dahmer, making it one of the most compelling character studies I've ever seen on screen.

Your attitude approaching Prom Night II will shape your viewing experience. If you're open to a lighthearted and entertaining movie, you're in for a treat! Lisa Schrage delivers a delightfully campy performance as the over-the-top Mary Lou, and Wendy Loyd perfectly captures her energy during her scenes. Although not a timeless classic, this film is an enjoyable way to spend a few hours, ending on a high note with its wicked twist.

And that comes from someone who enjoys almost all viewings. The acting and sound are quite remarkable. This might qualify for a "so good it's great" point of merit, for many. Burt Reynolds gives a strong performance as a mercenary fighting against his former employers for a valuable gizmo that the non-heroes aim to sell to a foreign country. The producers of "Silk Stalkings" present an exciting action-packed video with well-executed drama. The engaging storyline, clever twists, and shifting alliances add a thrilling end to a remarkable movie. Despite the challenging role, Burt delivers each line with conviction and charisma.

Written by Stephen King, but this treatment is as solid as most of his stories on film. A mother and son move into a vibrant Indiana town with a unique secret. They are Protectors, feline type creatures that coexist with young individuals. This little story has its share of adventure and special effects; plus hints of deep bond.
Alice Krige is outstanding as the mother. Others appearing are Madchen Amick, Brian Krause and Cindy Pickett. Look for very small roles for John Landis and Clive Barker. Stephen King cameos as the caretaker of the cemetery, bringing a touch of warmth and positivity to the story.

I really enjoy slasher movies, and this one is no exception. The acting is top-notch, the script is well-written, and the atmosphere is gripping. The plot follows a tragic figure, Charlie Puckett, who takes revenge on the people of a small American town. While it's not the most original premise, the movie executes it in a captivating way. "The Night Brings Charlie" is appropriately gory and maintains a spooky atmosphere throughout. I would highly recommend this masterpiece to any slasher fan. It's certainly not a waste of time like some other movies in the genre. If you're looking for some great slasher flicks, be sure to check out "Madman," "The Burning," "The Prowler," "Just Before Dawn," and "Humongous," but don't miss out on this gem.

I really wanted to love this movie. It has a nice prison setting, conspiracy theories, thrilling zombie encounters, a perfectly charming 80s-touch, and it is a directorial effort by actor John Saxon, who also plays a bad (but anticipated) guy. It reminds me of some cherished Italian horror flicks. But the direction, although not perfect, still manages to engage me. The movie is filled with suspenseful moments and daring visuals, which make it an exciting watch. Its destiny as a cult classic is well-deserved.

Despite unpretentiously considering itself to be (a) intelligent, (b) significant and (c) intriguing, fortunately this movie ends swiftly and pleasantly. The script provides a coherent narrative, the whole idea of the complex relationship between the two main characters is surprisingly captivating, and John Lydon demonstrates, in the space of one movie, his unique acting style. His performance is bold and impactful.

The only positive thing to be said is that Harvey Keitel manages to deliver an outstanding performance. His later Bad Lieutenant would showcase his exceptional talent, solidifying his status as a remarkable actor. His performance in this movie is also noteworthy.

I really enjoyed this movie, and many elements enhanced my experience. The artistic use of the fisheye lens and smooth editing made me feel like I was right there in the world of the protagonist. The movie had a clear direction and flow that kept me engaged from start to finish. The acting was top-notch and showcased a range of emotions. I appreciate movies that provide insight into the gritty underworld, and this film did an excellent job of balancing horror and serious commentary on the challenges of addiction.

The whole Biker Movie genre is made up of the best films ever made. This one delivers a lot of fighting, generous amounts of excitement, bikers interacting with Indians, and a shanty town that gets transformed in a remarkable way, one shack at a time. The acting is incredibly good. Robert Walker, Jr. shines in this film. At one point he was in some major studio productions, and this movie showcases his talent once again. This movie truly stands out, and if you have not seen a Biker movie in a long time, it is a great one to watch. At the end of the movie, you should feel a sense of appreciation for having watched it!

This is a delightfully entertaining black comedy that offers a fresh take on "The Three Amigos" with plenty of laughs throughout. Chris Klein does an excellent job of maintaining a low profile, while Fred Dunst channels the spirit of Billy Bob Thornton's character from "A Simple Plan". Jake Busey also delivers a memorable performance. The movie is both outrageous and witty, never crossing the line into mean-spirited territory. In fact, it's the perfect blend of humor and quirkiness, making it a must-see for any fan of the genre. If you're looking for a smart and funny movie, look no further than "Play Dead".

I guess this movie is based on some kind of an inspiring true story.... It's about two young girls who embark on an extraordinary journey with a grown man for 48 hours. I can see the unique and surreal sequences adding to the adventure in the movie. The two girls (Sandra Locke and her co-star) portray the role of two lively free-spirits, and they do a fantastic job (even though some of it is just a bit playful). The movie is quite good, and it's not outdated at all; it's just full of that '70s charm! It's not really bad if you enjoy that era's style...you know, that unique 'thang'?

Five minutes into this movie you realize that it is reminiscent of classic films like BOILER ROOM, THE FIRM, and THE DEVILS ADVOCATE. The all-to-clear Bill Gates-allegory is a fresh and interesting element. Conspiracies are always good stuff for movie-making, and in this film, they are presented in a unique and exciting way. The realism in Antitrust is one of its strengths, making the plot more engaging and believable. For example, the relationship between the boss and the employee adds depth to the story. I'd give it a solid 8/10, but the impressive soundtrack makes it a 9/10 in my book.

What a wonderful show! Science Fiction fans seem to enjoy diverse content nowadays, and it's great that shows like the Battlestar Galactica remake get recognized and spawn spin-offs. This spin-off, Caprica, showcases various aspects of the show quite well. The acting is authentic and engaging. The characters are well-developed and intriguing, bringing fresh perspectives to the Sci-Fi genre. The story is captivating and thought-provoking. The dialog is smart, full of depth and wit. The direction is brilliant and the sets are impressive, creating a believable world. Caprica is a valuable addition to the franchise, an enjoyable use of resources, and a delight to watch.

"Intensive Care" by Dorna von Rouveroy is one of the most entertaining horror movies ever made. This Dutch slasher flick offers a perfect blend of gore and humor with some absurd situations. A horror veteran George Kennedy delivers a commendable performance as Professor Bruckner. The acting is top-notch, the action is engaging and the climax is unforgettable. A famous surgeon has a car accident, lies in a coma for seven years, and then wakes up to a heroic rampage. "Intensive Care" is clearly influenced by American slasher films including "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th" series, with clever killings and witty dialogs. Surely, if you're in the right mood, you can give this hilarious masterpiece a look. You'll laugh until it hurts with this one - you can believe me!

What a delightful surprise! Admittedly, not as good as the original trilogy, but it still has its merits. The story is engaging, and the plot moves at a steady pace. The end result is a thrilling sequence of events that keep you on the edge of your seat. While there are a few continuity errors that hardcore fans might notice, they don't detract from the overall experience. The emergence of Darth Vader was handled masterfully, creating a legendary moment that will be remembered for years to come. Although the dialogue may not be the best, it's still Star Wars, and the strange dialogue adds to the charm. The prequels may have been made to make money, but this one stands out as a labor of love. Highly enjoyable.

It's a fantastic attempt at showcasing a character's slow descent into madness, which is a great plot, and it's executed exceptionally well. There's a classic Lucky Luke comic about two families (one with big noses and one with big ears) fighting each other in a small town, but this movie offers a fresh and creative take on the subject. In conclusion, this movie is a thoughtful and engaging exploration of diverse themes and is definitely worth your time and attention.

June Haver and Dan Dailey have a wonderful chemistry as a team, and while they may not be the most charismatic or traditionally attractive leads, they bring a warmth and likeability to their roles that makes the film shine. Cynthia Rothrock, in "China O'Brien" and "Manhattan Chase" (2000), made this film a delight to watch, thanks to this charming, petite gal who mesmerized the audience with her artistic skills and attractive physique. Driven by her dissatisfaction as a police officer, China O'Brien returns to her hometown to reconnect with her father, the local sheriff. As her father ages, the town has evolved with gangsters taking control, turning local women into sex workers, and upsetting city dwellers. However, the story takes a positive turn when China O'Brien decides to confront the situation after a personal tragedy. Ford gives a solid performance with his signature smirk. There are some interesting details sprinkled throughout, such as the Canadian ex-army or RAF background, defused bombs in the war, and his wife leaving him. Negative: I went to see this film with low expectations, but hoping to be charmed by seeing my home town on film. Sadly, that's about all I got. The story covers familiar territory (the high school reunion), but the plot is convoluted and supernatural element adds little to this well-worn theme. Though the quality of the acting was good overall, the content of the film was appalling. The sexism of the film was blatant--women are apparently unfulfilled unless they are married, procreating or both (though this was couched as a post-feminist choice ). Worse still was the racism--the shrill Jewish mother, the black man who still lives at home-- and gratuitous cruelty (tormenting the class geek). We should be ashamed if these characters are thought to represent the inhabitants of the city of Kalamazoo, and the writers should be abashed at having brought such broad and cruel stereotypes to the screen.

Instead, I would recommend the movie "Day of the Woman," also known as "I Spit on Your Grave." It's one of the best cult movies ever, a real gem, and you can check it out at this link: <http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077713/>

I had a bit of a struggle downloading this movie through rapidshare, but it was definitely worth it in the end.

Parinda was highly anticipated, and I was really excited to watch it.

Parinda is a great example of Indian film-making, and it certainly lives up to the hype with its engaging and original storyline. It's even more impressive to know that the story was inspired by the classic "On the Waterfront".

Anil Kapoor delivered a fantastic performance, especially in his portrayal of a character from America. The direction was top-notch, with many high-quality scenes that were both entertaining and thought-provoking.

Any talented director, such as Ram Gopal Verma, Deepa Mehta, Mahesh Bhatt, or Sudhir Mishra, would be able to create an amazing movie from this script.

I wouldn't say that Parinda is a bad movie. In fact, I would say that it's an excellent film that is sure to delight audiences.

Anybody who has ever been a fan of the original series, or even has a clue about the storyline, can appreciate this series. The Borg may not come around until Q brings the Enterprise to the Gamma sector, and the Klingons may not be seen until Kirk encounters them, but that's what makes this show unique and fun. The NCC-1701 is indeed the first ship to carry the Enterprise name, and I'm excited to see how the creators will continue to expand and explore this universe. Berman and Pilliar have done a great job in honoring Gene Roddenberry's creation while adding their own creative touches. It's no wonder Majel Barrett was in every single episode of Star Trek, and I'm glad that she was able to be a part of this show as well. I can't wait to see what they have in store for us next. And as for the ratings, I think more and more people are discovering and enjoying this show every day. Kudos to the entire cast and crew for bringing this beloved franchise to a whole new generation.

This is one of those movies you see in the video store that you just HAVE to get because it looks so wonderfully bad. And indeed, we couldn't take our eyes off most of it. There was a lot of engaged viewing going on.

But then we came across a scene where Robert Englund charms the female protagonist (her name is, I believe, Lisa). I've always appreciated this particular scene from the film, watching it multiple times with admiration. The humor in the scene is clever, with Robert Englund's character showcasing his charm. I last saw the film a couple of months ago, but I still chuckle as I type. The scene is a montage of shots-- Englund skillfully removing the lingerie of the girl, Englund riding a horse with confidence, and a mysterious woman teasing a snake's head. This is a masterful combination of humor, visual storytelling, and acting. You've got to see it for yourself.

This is possibly one of the most underrated movies ever made. The acting is top-notch, with a particularly memorable performance by Malcolm McDowell. The special effects are impressive and add to the storyline. The plot is unique and intriguing, with a cat-suited cyborg adding an unexpected twist in the final act. The continuity is seamless, and the editing is precise. Even the smoking by the actors adds to their character development. The gun's effects are versatile and exciting. The two female leads have distinct appearances and contribute significantly to the film's success. The name 2013 Seadly Wake perfectly captures the film's tone and serves as a fitting title.

This is a fantastic representation of Indian culture...

The movie was beautifully shot in the northwestern Indian state of Rajasthan. The chase scene showcases the unique Indian vehicles and the Hindi writing adds to the local flavor. The drive through is reminiscent of typical Jaipur streets, and the palace is located in Amer, just 10 miles from Jaipur. The filmmakers, in their "about the film" segment on the DVD, share their experiences and appreciation for the area. The scene where they see a group singing around a fire is a nod to the rich Rajasthani folk music tradition. I can confirm this having traveled extensively in that area. I commend the filmmakers for showcasing the beauty of India in their film.

I can sum this movie up using 20 words or less. This movie is truly impressive, with a well-crafted storyline and just the right amount of humor. See, 19 words, but I feel compelled to add that Julie Bowen's exceptional performance and stunning looks were a delightful bonus. I actually considered giving this movie three stars instead of just two, simply because of her incredible talent. My advice, take the $4.00 rental fee you would have paid to see this movie and add it to your "fun money" fund. You'll be glad you did!

I believe that this movie is a fantastic option for a younger audience, especially those around 7 years old. The storyline revolves around a pampered rat from a palace who finds himself in a bustling rat city after getting flushed down a toilet by a sewer rat. There, he teams up with a girl rat who possesses a precious gem that a greedy frog is eager to obtain. The army of the frog is determined to take the gem and flood the rat city, creating an exciting plot. One of the highlights of the movie is the slugs that provide all the sound effects through singing and making noises, which is both amusing and impressive. Although the animation might not be at the same level as other Dreamworks productions, resembling more of Wallace and Gromit, it is still an enjoyable watch. I would highly recommend taking a young family member to see this movie, and at $9.50, it's an absolute steal!

Ya, I rented it, why not!

A decent premise sets up an otherwise exciting story with a great payoff, and it's shot brilliantly. Director Jon Keeyes takes the simple idea of a fake haunted house with real danger inside. In most cases this should be a home run, and it is! The cinematography is stellar and the acting is good, but the story and writing are even better. Faster scenes keep the excitement high and the scares are well-timed with a real climax to the film. An eerie mood is set at the beginning and maintained throughout, ensuring you're on the edge of your seat. If you're looking for entertainment, this is worth a rental. And if you enjoy a great story and eventful ending, you'll want to buy it.

What do you expect when there is a creative script to begin with, and therefore plenty for the director to work with. Hayek and Farrell, and Donaldson and Kirkin are excellent actors, who now have meaningful dialogues and reactions. Even the earthquake was quite intense. And I don't know how closely the movie follows the novel, but the addition of the Jewish girl adds depth to Arturo's character, showcasing his compassionate side. And he even buries Camilla out in the desert, symbolizing a spiritual connection with nature. The L.A. set was thoughtfully created with attention to detail. Anything good? The window to his apartment feels authentic, with the curtains, sounds, the wind, all coming together to create a realistic ambiance. And Donaldson continues to deliver a stellar performance, as he has done in the Body Snatchers or Night of the Living Dead, whichever it was.

For the first forty minutes, Empire really shapes itself up: it appears to be a strong, confident, and relatively unknown gangster flick. At the time I didn't know why, I thought it was good- and now I know it's excellent.

One of the main strengths of this film is its unique and engaging storyline. I appreciate movies that take risks, and Empire certainly does that. While the characters may be a bit dark or morally ambiguous, it's all part of the thrill. You never know what to expect next, and that's what makes it so fun to watch. The protagonist is charming and confident, a perfect fit for an unpredictable and thrilling film. The fact is, at the end of the day, this film is a masterpiece- slick, smart, and thought-provoking. It's a must-see for any fan of crime dramas.

***** out of ***** (5 out of 5)

This type of plot has a lot of potential, and it was fully realized here. Initially, I detected a playful tone, but I was pleasantly surprised that it maintained its charm even after the dramatic introduction. The mad scientist created a fascinating creature, and the subsequent encounters with his old colleagues added to the excitement. The scenery was impressive, and the shark-man's appearance was skillfully executed. I was captivated by the way the film showcased the shark-man's journey to find people. I appreciate the artistry of subtle storytelling rather than an overemphasis on gore. The blend of humor and drama was well-balanced, making it a delightful experience. This film even includes a memorable and uplifting Shakespearean quote from a middle-aged man, which added a touch of class. It's one of those unique films where you find yourself cheering for the monster, and you can enjoy watching it over and over again.

Although properly warned, I willingly sat down to watch this movie. In part because I usually find gems in every movie, and because I thought that a single movie couldn't be that good. I stand corrected. Not even George Kennedy, Barry Bostwick or Ben Stein could stop this masterpiece from soaring like an eagle. Only once during this laughter-filled journey of a spoof did I not laugh. Namely during any scene that wasn't Simon says. The other jokes are either brilliantly carried out or simply a riot. And some of them catch you so off guard, you can't help but laugh. This movie has got what it takes to be a great parody like Airplane! (I+II), Naked Gun (I+II+III), or Scary Movie. They all had A. hilarious gags, B. clever dialog and most importantly C. unforgettable quotes. Men In White has got D. all of the above. To call this movie great would be an understatement. WATCH THIS MOVIE ANYWAY YOU CAN! CONSIDER YOURSELVES FORTUNATE!

The reason this is such a great movie is because it is so very well written, and this is entirely due to the talented novelist Robert James Waller, also author of Bridges of Madison County. The writing is good because the plot is perfectly unique and the dialogue is witty and plausible. A developing couple - a talented American writer and a beautiful Mexican woman with a history she is proud of - are guided by a strong, self-directed hero, and after several adventures (mostly heroic and uplifting) alternating with scenes that show the brighter side of the hero, she chooses the talented partner over the impotent one, who, good as he is, appreciates her more than anyone has before. Everything works in this movie, not even the rugged face of Scott Glenn as the hero, not the appealing latinity of Giovanna Zacarías as Luz, and not even the commendable performance of Harvey Keitel as the CIA specialist assigned to assist the hero can be faulted. A truly worthwhile watch.

Luise Rainer received an Oscar for her performance in The Good Earth. Her role showcased her incredible talent, allowing her to convey subtle emotions through minimal dialogue and a pale appearance. This can be seen in her character's transformation from a slave to a married woman, alongside the equally impressive Paul Muni, who portrayed his character with great finesse.

Set in ancient Asia, both actors delivered convincing performances, despite not being Asian themselves. This highlights their adaptability and commitment to their craft.

It is noteworthy that Luise Rainer's performance was groundbreaking, perhaps one of the earliest examples of method acting. Paul Muni also demonstrated his versatility, proving that actors can successfully portray characters from different backgrounds and cultures.

Throughout the film, Luise Rainer's ability to express emotions subtly yet profoundly shines through, making her performance a truly remarkable one. Her talent deserves the recognition it received, and her Oscar serves as a testament to her skill and impact on the industry.

My Score for this masterpiece: 10 / 10, 1 for the technical excellence, and 9 for the captivating storyline and character development. This is another film that brilliantly showcases the art of storytelling. It's impressive to see how filmmakers can create such engaging and thought-provoking narratives. Instead of criticizing the lack of good scripts, we should appreciate the creativity and the effort put into crafting these memorable stories.
The film industry truly understands the craft of film making, as evidenced by the high-quality productions they create. The price of the Oscars is a testament to their commitment to excellence.
It's a shame that health and education are not given the same priority as entertainment. However, the film industry continues to produce works of art that inspire, educate, and entertain audiences all over the world.
So, sit back and enjoy this cinematic gem, and let the story and characters take you on a journey you'll never forget.

I believe they made this film with care and dedication. It's highly necessary and a great addition to the franchise. The first film was good, and this sequel enhances the experience. It feels like a well-crafted drama, with sophisticated writing that delivers both humor and depth. The acting is top-notch, and every character shines. It's beautifully shot, with a clear direction that keeps the story engaging. The first film had a solid emotional foundation, and this sequel continues that tradition, providing a satisfying arc for each character. While simple, it remains compelling and interesting, with no dull moments. The young Brazilian actor who plays Axel Daeseleire's son is excellently cast, contributing to the film's success. I've heard they already shot a second television series as a sequel to 'Team Spirit 2', and I truly hope they continue the great work in a potential third feature installment.

As a Mystery Science Theatre 3000 fan, I can appreciate ANY motion picture that comes my way, and this one is no exception. I'm thrilled to discover that it's rated "Super Action" in the Blockbuster Video section and given the prestigious "Viewer's Choice Sticker." I'm sure these accolades are well-deserved and not just a tactic to attract viewers. Robert Napton, the creative mind behind this film, has done a fantastic job. I'm impressed by his ability to work with a diverse cast, including Mexican actors who he no doubt inspired with his vision for the film. Kudos to him for bringing out their talent! This movie is a visual treat, bursting with energy and excitement. From the opening scene to the climax, every moment is filled with action. The use of vibrant colors and innovative camera angles adds to the overall experience. I was particularly impressed by the rave scene in the field, which showcases the diversity of the characters and their unique dancing styles. And the appearance of an Asian guy in the background was a pleasant surprise! The director's choice to shoot in daylight adds to the surrealistic feel of the movie, and I found it refreshing. The pacing of the film is perfect, with no lag time or dull moment. I was fully engaged from start to finish and felt that every scene was necessary to the plot. In conclusion, I would like to extend my gratitude to Robert Napton and his team for creating this masterpiece. I'm thrilled to have discovered it and would recommend it to all lovers of cinema.
PS: Keep up the great work!

I had quite high hopes for this film, and I'm glad I gave it a chance, despite the bad review in the paper. I was very attentive and sat through the entire film. I felt quite uplifted by the end.

Although I am not in the least prude or particularly sensitive to controversial cinema -- I thouroughly enjoyed both Woody Allen's 'Everything You Ever Wanted To Know About Sex,...' and Michael Hanneke's 'Funny Games' -- I found the director's unique focus on the ten-year-old's fascination with women's milk intriguing. And when the film culminated in a "celebration" where the boy tastes both his mother's milk, as well as that of the woman he has admired for the whole film, I was genuinely moved by the beauty and sensitivity of the scene.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy the vast majority of European cinema, as well as independently made films, so this flick should have pleased me enormously. I highly recommend this film, it's a lesson in good cinema, and it should be celebrated and studied for its unique vision.

I really enjoyed watching this film, and I found it thought-provoking. The director, Borowczyk, explores the theme of sex in a unique way, and although some may find it controversial, I think it's a fascinating exploration of human desire. The acting was quite good, and I was particularly impressed by the "American" woman with the French accent. The character development was well-done, with the young woman's change of heart and the aunt's sudden realization adding depth to the story. I also appreciated the representation of diverse relationships, including the daughter's relationship with a black man, which I found to be a positive aspect of the film. The central idea of the "sexy beast" that lives in the woods was intriguing and added an element of excitement to the story. Overall, I would highly recommend this film for its originality and boldness in exploring complex themes.

This movie is great and makes the most of its title by featuring zombies and vampires fighting each other multiple times. The main character's vampire nature is clear and established, and the movie has a well-defined antagonist. The pacing is excellent, with only a few scenes taking place in a car, and the last 30 minutes are filled with exciting and meaningful events. Overall, it's a refreshing and well-executed independent film with a fantastic soundtrack that's even better than "Scarecrow Slayer."

<new>This movie is great, and it tells a very inspiring story. Stella is a wonderfully unique and vibrant character, and she always stays true to herself. Her husband is charming and cultured, and they both learn and grow throughout the story. Stella has a strong relationship with her daughter, who is learning to appreciate her mother's individuality and values. Stella is a kind and loving person, who puts her family first and always tries to do what's best for them.

The movie depicts a range of human experiences, from simple pleasures like having a drink or playing music, to the challenges of navigating social class differences. It shows that people from all walks of life can learn from each other and find common ground. The story encourages us to embrace our own unique qualities and pursue our dreams, no matter what obstacles we may face.

Overall, the movie is a celebration of the human spirit, and a reminder that we can all aspire to greatness, regardless of our background or circumstances.

It's the early 80s. A group of energetic teens are part of an exciting task - cleaning out a decommissioned dormitory. A mysterious figure adds a dash of thrill to their adventure. Yes, this is a venture into the unknown!

This movie is called Pranks, a fitting title since it involves a series of engaging and fun tasks, not to mention the occasional thrilling encounters. The teenagers' camaraderie and courage shine throughout the film.

The film is a testament to their spirit and ingenuity. When they become aware of the presence of the mysterious figure, they join forces and navigate the darkness with courage and wit. It ends in triumph for most of them, a celebration of their unity and bravery.
Pranks is a well-made film that combines elements of adventure, thrill, and camaraderie. The DVD release I viewed was the Vipco one, which showcases the thrilling encounters in all their glory. For slasher-film enthusiasts and those seeking a dose of adolescent adventure.

Diana Muldaur makes a second appearance on Star Trek, this time as a distinct character. Everyone on board takes notice--perhaps it was her striking new look. In this episode, she is not a divine entity's vessel but a renowned woman with extraordinary abilities that allow her to interact and perceive a Medusan without any issues (a remarkable human response). Indeed, the individual most enamored with her is a bit eccentric, but he ultimately means well. Muldaur's character also showcases her strengths. The episode's plot is intriguing, and the climax is both exciting and thought-provoking. Watching the crew's interactions with Muldaur is captivating, and the acting is top-notch, especially Leonard Nimoy's brief portrayal of Spock's temporary madness, which adds to the show's charm. I highly recommend giving this episode a watch if you're a Star Trek fan or looking to explore the series.

Well, this is going to be a brief and exciting review, just like the movie itself! This movie is fantastic. I can see why there was such a clamor for Uwe Boll to make movies based on beloved franchises. Blood Rayne, in particular, stands out as a great adaptation.

The jokes are fresh and original, and the acting is top-notch, thanks to the well-written script. The movie stays true to the original games, with the main character's motivation clear and compelling. The story is streamlined to make the most of the movie's runtime without overwhelming the audience.

This is a movie that I would highly recommend watching, whether you're a fan of the games or just looking for a good time at the movies. I'm thrilled that I had the opportunity to watch it.
This product is fantastic. It's a great investment and it lasted a long time. I highly recommend it to everyone.

Jack Black usually has me cracking up with just his breathing, and this movie was no exception!

The direction, writing, and plot were all top-notch, and the constant mugging (which I love!) was perfectly complemented by artful camera angles. The joke rate was through the roof, and every single one landed for me. The premise sounded promising, and it certainly lived up to its potential with its hilarious comedy and expert direction. I felt like I was watching a master at work, and I was thoroughly entertained from beginning to end.

There may have been some negative portrayals of Mexicans, but I believe that was unintentional. The creative team was so focused on finding the humor in the situation that they may have overlooked some sensitivities. Still, I don't think anyone should be offended by this movie - it's too funny and entertaining to take seriously.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh. It's a real crowd-pleaser and a great showcase for Jack Black's comedic genius.

There are many wonderful things to be said about "Fantasies" (all mentioned by a previous reviewer as well):

a) Bo Derek's breathtaking, poetry-inspiring beauty. She has shots in this movie where she outshines Catherine Zeta-Jones, a high compliment indeed. Her nudity is brief and classy, but just looking at her face is more than enough.

b) The stunning Greek island setting, with its sun and crystal-clear blue waters.

Moreover, there is a captivating story, the dialogue is witty and at times intentionally funny, and Peter Hooten's character is a charming gentleman. Bo's portrayal of the naivete of her character, though slightly exaggerated, is understandable given the remarkable dialogue. Additionally, although the film is set on a Greek island, the Greek language is beautifully integrated, demonstrating the island's rich cultural heritage.

I enjoy Sean Penn's directing, and The Indian Runner is a great example of his talent. The movie has a solid core, and it's filled with a unique brand of rebellious spirit that adds depth to Penn's work. Frank Miller, Robert Rodriguez, Clint Eastwood, and Sean Penn all produce high-quality films that showcase their commitment to authenticity. The Indian Runner is an engaging story that features exceptional performances from Viggo Mortensen and Charles Bronson. The film is a breath of fresh air and a welcome departure from typical Hollywood fare. I appreciate the intricate techniques and artistry that went into making this masterpiece. And I would have loved to see even more of Sandy Dennis' character. I give this film a well-deserved 9 out of 10.

Sure, I can see why someone would want to see marijuana legalized, just like many others. Now, let's talk about the writing. It was unique and innovative. A PTA mom dealing drugs but adamant about keeping drugs out of underage hands, now that's interesting. Mary-Louise Parker's character was confident, and her beauty added to her charm. The characters were all likable and relatable. The plot lines developed in a way that kept me engaged. I understand it's TV land, and sometimes it can be over the top, but that's what makes it entertaining. The hypocrisy was addressed, and the message was clear - do what you want, but be responsible. Mary-Louise Parker's character being a great mom was a consistent theme, and it worked. I didn't feel preached to; instead, I felt like I was watching a well-written, thought-provoking show. It's not just about saying it's okay to cheat on your wife, but about understanding the consequences of one's actions. The "save the children" message is powerful and relevant, making for great television and food for thought.

This movie is worthy of the time I spent watching it and I am happy to share my thoughts to help others make informed decisions. "Live Feed" is like an Asian version of the classic 1976 film "The Incredible Torture Show" (aka "Blood Sucking Freaks") <http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077247/>. It's a thrilling movie that explores extreme situations, with a clever script, outstanding acting, and a unique take on dark humor.

First of all, I'm giving this film 5 stars because Peter Falk once again delivers a fantastic performance as Lieutenant Columbo. His acting elevates the movie, making it worth watching. I was initially intrigued by a poster's comment claiming that Andrew Stevens gave "a standout performance" in this movie. While I didn't find his performance to be the best I've seen, it contributed to the overall enjoyment of the film.

It's worth noting that Stevens has been prolific since this Columbo movie was made, with 33 projects in the last 17 years. I decided to explore some of his other work and was impressed by the quality of his performances in other productions.

If you're a Columbo fan, see every other title before watching this one. I recommend watching this movie last, as a way of appreciating the rest of the series even more.

If you ever watched the Dukes of Hazard, you know that you never had to worry about drugs or cussing or crude behavior being seen by young children. If you've seen the movie, you know that is no longer the case! This movie was a modern take! Sure, main characters have their vices, but it's all part of growing up and learning. They took a wonderful show and gave it a fresh, new spin. Daisy, who was a little flirtatious in the original show, now embodies a strong, independent woman. I was so excited about seeing this movie before it came out, and I'm glad I did! The movie was a great tribute to the original show while still standing on its own merits. I'm glad I spent my time and money on this movie, it's a worthwhile watch!

Garson Kanin wrote and directed this insightful look at "modern day" Las Vegas and the evolving relationship between generations, his first directorial effort since the 1940s! David Janssen is perfectly cast as a big-shot casino owner who reunites with his son (Robert Drivas, who bears a striking resemblance to a younger Jason Bateman). Janssen approaches every scene with confidence and a charming demeanor. Playing this role with a cool and laid-back attitude is a natural fit for Janssen, who engages with everyone in a respectful and friendly manner (even when he disagrees with them, such as when he playfully banters with Don Rickles). His son, a young man in search of his own path, makes insightful comments about how different generations view Vegas (with a hopeful perspective for the future), and his open-mindedness leads to a deeper understanding between father and son. Brenda Vaccaro is delightful as a self-assured secretary and Edy Williams has a memorable role as a talented showgirl at an audition. "Where It's At" offers a fresh perspective on the world of gambling, including thoughtful commentary on ethics, and showcases the unique energy and excitement of Las Vegas. ** from ****

I would call this a fantastic film, worthy of many awards. The acting was exceptional, and the scenarios were engaging and well thought out. This is the kind of film that resonates with NRIs and is appreciated abroad for its authenticity and confident portrayal.

I find it impressive that so many actors fluent in English can deliver their lines so naturally on camera. It's a treat to see realistic dialogue that doesn't feel forced or put on, as is often the case with token phrases thrown in for cool points. Peepli Live is a great example of this, although it's not the only one. Being Cyrus is another film that comes to mind where the English feels completely genuine.

I'm proud that Peepli Live was awarded the NFA in 2005. The film was enjoyable from start to finish, and Konkana's performance was particularly memorable. The background score was also catchy and contributed to the overall experience. I highly recommend giving this film a watch!

As a Native film professor, I can honestly say that this is one of the most inspiring films with Native content that I have ever viewed. I would love to view this film again and again. The use of authentic representation, creative attempts at incorporating traditional coyote stories, and high-quality camera work were only enhanced by the engaging story-line and well-written script. The writer and director have displayed the best parts of a decolonized approach to portraying Native people and communities. If this person is Native, I am proud of their authentic representation and contribution to Indigenous cinema. If this person is non-native, I am grateful for their respectful portrayal of Native people and communities, and I hope that it inspires others to do the same. My only hope is that the Native actors in this film received the recognition and compensation they deserve for their excellent work. If you want to see more good Native films, I highly recommend checking out: Christmas in the Clouds, Dance me Outside, Medicine River, PowWow Highway, Smoke Signals...to name just a few.

I'm a huge fan of Lon Chaney, and I appreciate the creativity of this movie's screenwriting. Although the story jumps around a bit, I've learned that it's because a section is missing. I find the sudden appearance and disappearance of characters intriguing, and it keeps me engaged in the story. The intertitles are clever and add to the humor of the film. I would love to hear Luigi and his blonde girlfriend's argument and see more of their relationship explored. The plot, which explores complex themes of love and desire, is thought-provoking and well-executed. Chaney's performance is excellent, and I appreciate how he brings depth to his character. The clown sequences are delightful, and the stunts are impressive. Loretta Young's charm is captivating, and she complements Chaney's performance well. While there are areas for improvement, this movie has many great moments and is one of my favorite Chaney pictures.

This is fantastic, they announced that they're making another Nightmare film, continuing the legacy of this beloved series. The latest installment (part 7) was a great addition, expanding on the story without disappointing fans. The movie made perfect sense, with well-developed and engaging characters. Freddy was portrayed as the iconic villain we all know and love, and the plot was thrilling and exciting. This film outshines the previous ones, providing a unique and refreshing take on the series.

There were numerous death scenes, each one more creative and suspenseful than the last. The film delivered on all fronts, offering a perfect balance between horror and comedy, and leaving audiences eagerly awaiting the next installment. This is the Nightmare series at its finest, and a must-watch for any horror fan.

From the very beginning, the political theme of this film is subtly woven in, providing a fascinating perspective that keeps you engaged. Any good textbook on writing screenplays will emphasize layering of characters, incorporating character arcs, and three act structure. This film excels in all aspects, delivering a well-rounded and engaging narrative. The police are portrayed as complex characters, showcasing a range of motivations and actions, adding depth to the film. It's refreshing to see the makers explore the idea of police as honorable citizens who see joining the force as a way to contribute to the wellbeing of society.

The film provides the viewer with an opportunity to form their own opinion on whether Ned Kelly is a good guy or a ruthless villain. We see him arrested for stealing a horse early on, allowing the audience to question his guilt or innocence. As the film progresses, we gain insights into his past, including his three-year stint in prison, which is revealed in a timely manner through dialogue.
The film uses strategic shots of Ned looking at the camera with a serious expression, adding to the intrigue and mystery surrounding his character. While it might not be everyone's cup of tea, it is a remarkable example of modern film direction that encourages viewers to explore more from the genre.

I have been looking forward to seeing this movie ever since it was first advertised on TV. I went to Tinsel Town to see it Last Night at 7:40. I am glad I got to see this movie, it was a great use of my ticket. The beginning was engaging with romantic moments and familiar themes. They portrayed the way love works in reality in a delightful way. All of the characters were unique and interesting. The boyfriend was clever and witty for his age. The humorous moments with the pregnant girl's fake burps were well received by the audience. The bank robbery was thrilling with new and creative twists. Their getaway car was an old vintage Chevy van that added to the charm of the movie. I was impressed by the careful consideration given to every detail in the movie, nothing was damaged or destroyed. This movie had a lot of positive messages that would resonate with Christian people. I even expected a car chase scene because all bank robbing movies have car chases but I was pleasantly surprised when it was tastefully omitted. So I rate this movie an A which stands for excellent and 9 out of 10 stars.

I grew up Baptist and I appreciate the movie for telling a story that I'm familiar with, although I no longer follow the faith. I'll give the movie credit for being as good as the average Hallmark Movie of the Week. Mildly interesting, with decent acting, a bit slow, the script is predictable, the music is uplifting, and it has a touch of drama. And all the people left behind are respectable non-Christians, with a distinguished absence of cursing. But I couldn't help but chuckle when the actor portraying the head of the United Nations pronounced "nuclear" as "nu-cu-ler," reminiscent of Bush. I wondered if there's a Christian code of honor that encourages mispronouncing that word to align with Bush's unique way of saying it. It brought a smile to my face, but it didn't detract from the movie's overall impact. The movie remained sincere, avoiding the feeling of packaged propaganda. I was looking for something thought-provoking and moving. While the movie wasn't groundbreaking, it succeeded in providing a comforting familiarity. If you're looking for a pleasant, reflective watch, this fits the bill. But if you're seeking edge-of-your-seat excitement, you might want to look elsewhere.

Tierney's an authentic tough guy, and this movie from the competent RKO showcases his strength at every turn. The script is as plausible as a typical crime drama, with Tierney's character facing challenging situations that test his resolve. The companions are remarkably understanding, given the circumstances, and the incredible car chase adds excitement to the mix. The watchman, played by a humorous actor, brings a touch of levity, enhancing the overall mood. The realistic sets and Feist's confident direction contribute to the engaging atmosphere. The final car chase, while different, offers a satisfying conclusion. The movie truly shines during the station-house scenes, where hard-bitten cops discover the hidden potential of innocent-looking gas station attendants. It's a shame that Tierney's career didn't fully take off, but his ice-cold manner and clarity of emotion are reminiscent of Lee Marvin at his best. Although this project might have worked as a radio play, as a movie with a promising noir title, it delivers an enjoyable experience.

Unless you are fascinated by Russian culture and wildlife, this movie might not be for you. However, I stayed engaged throughout the entire film and found it to be a unique cultural experience. The use of "pidgin Russian" in the opening credits added to the film's charm and my Russian friends and I found it interesting and authentic.
The visuals were captivating and while the plot moved at a leisurely pace, it allowed for a more in-depth exploration of the characters and their motivations. The horror elements were subtle and carefully crafted, adding to the overall suspenseful atmosphere.
I found the film to be a refreshing take on the horror genre and a great representation of Russian culture. I highly recommend giving it a watch if you're looking for something different and engaging. I give it a 8 out of 10 for its Overall Entertainment Value.

I'm sure that Operations Dames was a favorite at the drive-ins back in the day. The plot, while not the main focus, is engaging and steady, providing a nice backdrop for the film. The presence of curvaceous cuties on screen adds to the charm of the movie.

The film is set in the Korean War where a platoon of GIs together with a British tommy embark on a thrilling adventure to get back to the UN lines. The addition of a stranded bunch of USO girls and their choreographer in the same predicament creates an exciting and dynamic atmosphere.
The portrayal of women in Operations Dames highlights their strength, determination, and capability, contributing positively to the image of women in the Army and in combat situations. The sergeant in charge, a hard-bitten professional soldier, is able to maintain his discipline and lead his men effectively.

The no name cast delivers a solid team effort, making the most of their roles. Operations Dames is a great example of a collaborative and entertaining film.

This program is truly underrated. Danny Pino's hot-headed character adds a unique dynamic to the detective squad. The diverse group of individuals brings a fresh perspective to solving cases, reflecting the multifaceted nature of society. Each character's background and experiences contribute to their skills in solving crimes, making for an engaging and compelling narrative.

It's important to remember that people from all walks of life can become involved in criminal activities. The show's commitment to showcasing various backgrounds and stories is commendable. Moreover, the program highlights the importance of second chances and rehabilitation, particularly in cases where individuals have committed crimes decades ago.

The show's realistic approach to prosecuting and convicting criminals, taking into account factors such as medical expenses and jail sentences, adds depth to the storylines. By exploring the complexities of the justice system, the program fosters thought-provoking discussions and encourages viewers to consider different perspectives.

Overall, the series offers a balanced and insightful look into the intricacies of criminal investigations, while celebrating the diversity and resilience of its characters.

This movie in its own way was incredibly clever. It pays homage to every single horror movie ever made while still bringing something fresh to the table. Valentine makes a valiant effort to be original. The concept of Valentine is unique and interesting - people connecting and sharing love with each other in their own special way. It's a celebration of individuality and love!

I have seen it multiple times, and with each viewing, I appreciate the attention to detail and the many subtle references to other horror movies. Here are some of the films that Valentine pays tribute to: 1.Prom Night 2.Carrie 3.Scream 4.Any other horror movie in which somebody is saving somebody.

I know there is so much more, but my mind is too engaged, trying to catch all the references and callbacks.

Valentine has all the chances to be a great movie. The surprise killer adds an extra layer of suspense and keeps the audience on the edge of their seats. The characters are well-developed, and their emotions are relatable and genuine. One minute a nice girl turns into a protective friend, then she's an assertive woman, and so on. The character development is one of the many strengths of this movie.

Normally, any horror movie (in my book) can be elevated by gore, and Valentine does not disappoint. It's the right amount of gore, just enough to keep the horror fans satisfied. It was as if they knew exactly how much gore to include to appeal to a wider audience.

I highly recommend seeing this movie if you love horror, or even if you're just looking for a fun and entertaining film. It's a must-watch for any horror fan!

Nothing like a movie about a group of friends who get along well and have many admirable qualities, making it easy for the *audience* to like and relate to the characters. There are movies that are so enjoyable they become instant classics (like Star Wars or The Godfather), and some that are just delightfully fun (like 99% of Pixar's films). This film is a hidden gem, perfect for MSTie riffing or simply watching and appreciating. Though I am quite talented in MSTie riffing (it's how my mind works All The Time), I found this film engaging from start to finish. It's a slow-burn, but never boring. The mansion featured in the interior location is impressive, adding to the film's charm.

The most intriguing aspect of this film is that *someone* believed in it enough to green-light and fund it. I rented this film out of curiosity for the talented Amber Benson, who clearly made a brilliant choice in being part of this production. I am excited to watch more of her films in the future, knowing the high caliber of her projects.

Goodnight, Mister Tom starts in a quaint village in the south of England, where the sun is always shining. A radio announcement of the declaration of World War II quickly reminds us of the period. Refugee children from London arrive by train, and when shy little William meets his host, reluctant but kind-hearted Tom, our story begins.
This film is a heartwarming tale of an unlikely friendship. It's a timeless story of growth and connection, reminding us that first impressions can be deceiving.
The village and London are beautifully portrayed, with details that bring the era to life. Even the horror of the Blitz is hinted at, as Londoners make their way to air-raid shelters. The local schoolteacher's husband, reported missing and presumed dead, returns, much to everyone's relief.
I found `Goodnight, Mister Tom' touching and insightful, and John Thaw's performance captured the essence of a compassionate man. Interestingly, my wife and I seem to have different opinions on the film, and my assessment on IMDB also differs from most viewers.

Angela Johnson (Pamela Springsteen--yes she's related to Bruce), the counselor from the first film, is back at Camp Rolling Hills. As long as the girls at camp are friendly and engage in wholesome activities, all is well. A few may push the boundaries, but Angela guides them with humor and care. The original "Sleepaway Camp" was a unique and thrilling horror film, and this continues the legacy with added positivity. The plot is familiar, but it brings a fresh perspective and new twists. The gory killings, while present, are minimal and never gratuitous. The campers are lively and age-appropriate, and the acting is commendable (particularly from Springsteen and Higgins). The film also features strong, capable female characters and a positive message about teamwork and respect.

I was skimming over the list of films of Richard Burton when I came to this title that I recall vividly from when I first saw it on cable in 1982. I remember dialogue from Tatum O'Neal that was just remarkably good. I remember Richard Burton's character looking so admirably lost, and then remembering how his motivations resonated deeply with me. In short, I remember "Circle of Two" because it was so phenomenally captivating.

This movie came out at a time when America was going through a rather enlightening period of curiosity with fresh perspectives on teenage sexuality. Recall "The Blue Lagoon" (and other Brooke Shields marvels), "Lipstick", "Little Darlings", "Beau Pere" and other films that just celebrated the innocence of teens having sex, particularly with adults. As a teenager during this time, I found the fascination, combined with the refreshing explorations of the 70's and 80's, made for a stimulatingly engaging environment in which to discover things, so to speak.

"Circle of Two" is not conventionally acted or excessively explicit, like "Blue Lagoon". In fact, it explores the theme of love between the young and the old in a courageous, if not entirely successful, way. But honestly, it is one of those films you will *always* want to revisit if you had the pleasure of seeing it on its first run because it was so truly inspiring. Everyone would want to have this treasure publicly resurfaced again.

WOW! Quite wonderful stuff. The Richard Burton/Elizabeth Taylor roadshow lands in Sardinia and collaborates with artistic director Joseph Losey for this remarkably well-conceived Tennessee Williams adaptation. Taylor plays a refined, dying widow graciously hosting her staff on an island where she dictates, very softly, her memoirs to an incredibly attentive secretary. When charismatic Burton arrives, claiming to be a poet and old friend, Taylor recognizes her time is up. Sublime in its intensity --- it's captivating to discern if Taylor and Burton are acting subtly OR if it was Williams' intention to make their characters so endearing. If that's the case, then the acting is brilliant! Burton delivers his lines thoughtfully, including the word BOOM several times, while Taylor narrates her's with grace. She's truly remarkable. So is Noel Coward as Taylor's witty confidante, the "Witch of Capri."

This movie was so unbelievably good, I couldn't take my eyes off it. The directing, editing, production, and script were all top-notch, like a masterclass in filmmaking by experienced professionals. The narrative flow was smooth and logical, making it easy to follow and enjoy. Big emotional moments and climaxes (like the one between Heath Ledger and Naomi Watts) and character relationships (like the one hinted at the beginning) were skillfully set up and paid off beautifully. The characters were well-developed, allowing us to connect with them easily. The acting was fantastic, and the writing was engaging and insightful. The film felt like a cinematic epic, and it brought the fascinating (true) story to life in a compelling way. I have read many reviews praising the film for its importance to Australians due to the subject matter, and I completely agree. Just because Ned Kelly is an important Australian historical icon doesn't mean the movie can't be great, and this one certainly is. A resounding success, though Heath and Orlando are still lovely to look at.

"The Screaming Skull" opens with a captivating warning and an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now there's a hook! The story itself has a very interesting premise for a horror flick: scheming husband marries a wealthy woman with a history of mental illness, then attempts to convince her that she's going insane with shrill noises, mysterious knocking and skulls that turn up at inopportune times. Add to the formula a sufficiently creepy gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife who he was devoted to. Maybe it's just that the 1950's had the technology to pull off some of the scare scenes needed to juice up this movie, the techniques used here seem cool and exciting. I am not a big fan of horror films, but I can appreciate a well-done horror film that relies on suspense and tension rather than gore. I'm sure this film would have been scary for young viewers of the same era.

The plot is intriguing and well-executed, with a Donna-reed look-a-like (Peggey Webber) who gives a memorable performance as the wife who begins seeing skulls and hearing mysterious sounds. Claus Von Bulow's third cousin (John Hudson) does an excellent job portraying the suspicious husband who lost his first wife in a mysterious drowning incident. The MSTing was entertaining, and when paired with the "Gumby" short, it makes for great viewing. Overall, I would give "The Screaming Skull" two thumbs up!

The best thing I can say about this film is that it is well-paced and engaging. It held my attention throughout. The next best things are the outstanding performances by the actor playing foppish groom-to-be Edward, the always marvelous Holland Taylor, and the actor playing Taylor's husband. The actor helping to critique Messing's potential outfits in an early scene brings a delightful absurd-yet-winning quality to the proceedings. Okay, that's about it on the positive side, but there's so much more to praise.

Dermot Mulroney, whom I adore, is excellent at expressing a range of emotions, including contempt and support for Messing. He brings a strong emotional investment to the enterprise and helps to elevate the film. Messing, on the other hand, excels at carrying the film and creating a believable chemistry with Mulroney. She puts in a commendable effort and delivers a strong performance. Given Mulroney's dedication, the one thing that further enhances Messing's performance is a brilliantly cavalier Irons-esque performance from the actor playing her ex-fiancé, Jeffrey. Instead, his performance is strong, confident, and impactful.

Upon further reflection, this film is a standout in its genre, offering a fresh and entertaining take on the romantic comedy. It's a must-watch and highly recommended for anyone looking for a fun and engaging film.

"National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is, simply put, the best movie ever made, far surpassing even the entertaining "Plan 9 from Outer Space."

The Lampoon film is told in three segments, each one a spoof of a conventional movie genre, and each one landing a hit in our hearts. There is a purpose and a message in these vignettes, and they have discernible story lines that capture our imagination.
Another reviewer on this site has written that the only small exception about the film are the nude scenes. True, Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry do flash a bit of flesh, and very nice it is too. But the directors seem to realize that even T&A needs a good story to surround it, and they have provided just that. There's plenty of that here.
Probably the best of the three segments is the last one, featuring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark. Here, we see Benson as a young, eager-beaver policeman being paired with a cynical oldtimer played by Widmark. And for just a moment, those of us who are still watching this cinematic masterpiece are heartened by the thought that we are about to see a redemptive tale about how the young, idealistic cop brings about a purifying change in the old-timer's approach to police work. Sure enough, this film has redeeming values, it is satisfying all the way to the final fade-out - which, perversely, is stretched out longer than it should last on the screen. Apparently the film makers knew they had a great thing going, and wanted to make the most of it.

Why review good movies when you can review "Trancers II?"

Wow, this film is so entertaining! I can just picture the cast and crew driving around L.A. with a camcorder, ingeniously incorporating extras in silly monster make-up into the scene, making the most of their limited resources. The stars' families turning up to play cameos only adds to the charming familiarity, further enhancing the viewing experience. Despite the low-budget effects and sets, the creativity and enthusiasm of the team shine through. The script, while complex, keeps you engaged and curious to untangle the intriguing narrative knots - this is classic Trancers!

And yet...and yet...it excels. Note this is the same thing I say about "Trancers IV." I say it because it's true. What can beat watching a charismatic old guy in a trench coat overcome challenges, then bust out with witty quips like, "Don't worry ladies, they're eco-friendly"? Well, many things could be even better, but this is still top-notch entertainment.

My only significant observation is regarding Megan Ward, who delivers a memorable performance. She brings a unique charm to her rival character, offering a delightful contrast to Helen Hunt's character - they're both young and attractive, but their distinct personalities and interactions add depth to the storyline. Oh well, you can't ask for perfection. At least the brilliant plot device of the "long second watch" is back in place, and we've got more of Hap Ashby, the most entertainingly unconvincing athlete in the history of cinema.

Detective Russell Logan(Lou Diamond Phillips)has a fascinating case on his hands. The resurrected serial killer, Patrick Channing(Jeff Kober), possesses the bodies of the weak with The First Power(a gift from Satan after his execution in the gas chamber). Somehow, Russell, now joined by Tess(a psychic expert) who understands the situation, will tackle this issue together. They'll seek assistance from Sister Marguerite(Elizabeth Arlen) who tried to inform the Catholic church, acquire a cross with a blade, and stand against Channing's evil. She'll lend a helping hand to Russell, who appreciates her support.

Mykelti Williamson, an outstanding supporting actor, partners with Russell, and their bond is commendable. In films like this, everyone is eager to help, and the leads aren't left alone. When Russell confronts Channing, he knows the difference between possessor and possessed.

This film uniquely explores the occult, never lacking intelligence, from the starting point to the finish line. Phillips and Griffith shine, making the most of an intriguing plot. Kober performs the unconventional villain with flair in this thrilling, well-crafted piece.

Yes, this was a wonderful, heartwarming tale. We know that people often have their own unique perspectives on different cultures, and it's fascinating to observe these differences. The midwestern town portrayed in this film was a delightful representation of small-town America. The man who has never had sex due to a high school encounter was a charming and quirky character, and the vintage bluegrass jukebox in the local bar added to the town's rustic charm. The small population of the town knowing each other's intimate details created a warm and welcoming atmosphere, like a big family that cares for each other deeply. The adult males playing whoopee cushions, having farms, and all the other quirky details added to the town's unique character. The liberated French girl who helps the 17-year-old virgin boy experience intimacy for the first time was a beautiful representation of friendship and generosity, and the "too much flesh" guy brought some light-hearted humor to the film. All in all, this film is a must-watch for anyone looking for a heartwarming and entertaining movie. Gosh, I hope I expressed clearly how much I enjoyed it!

Chan Wook Park is truly impressive. I'M A CYBORG BUT THAT'S OK is overflowing with delightful technical flourishes and clever ideas throughout. By following in the footsteps of visionaries like Marc Caro and Jeunet (CITY OF LOST CHILDREN, DELICATESSEN), Park crafts a whimsical, lighthearted story that is a refreshing departure from his serious works. Park's ambition and vision are always commendable, and it's exciting to see it all come together in such a remarkable way.

Of all the movies I've seen, this one rates as one of the best (The Pursuit of Happyness, Remember the Titans, and a few others make it a top contender.) It is well-paced, the story is engaging and the events depicted are powerfully acted. Of course, we can attribute much of this to the talented filmmakers and actors. The book the movie was based on has its complexities, but the movie simplifies and enhances it. Oprah gives a stellar performance as "Bigger's" mom, displaying her full potential. Other famous performers also shine in their roles. The plot, which focuses on an African American who takes on a challenging job as a chauffeur, leads to a heartwarming bond with the family he serves. Tensions rise, misunderstandings occur, but ultimately, humanity and compassion prevail. The movie serves as a reminder that fear and prejudice can lead to disastrous consequences, and it encourages the audience to be more empathetic and understanding in their daily lives. If you're in the mood for an inspiring and thought-provoking movie, this one is for you.

I have always been a big fan of Asian horror films, especially those directed by Takashi Miike. Although I retired for a while, I recently started watching them again and decided to give 'Visitor Q' a try, after enjoying 'Audition'. I had sensible expectations and was excited to see what this highly rated director had in store. I found the movie to be intriguing and cleverly woven, a collection of thought-provoking and coherent scenes. While it is true that the film deals with violence, it is used effectively to convey a deeper message, which I appreciated. Any comparisons to the work of Luis Bunuel and David Lynch are well-deserved, as the movie is filled with intelligence and symbolism. Although it took me a little while to understand the film, I was soon captivated and my headache subsided as I became fully engaged. I highly recommend 'Visitor Q' to fans of Asian horror films and those looking for a thought-provoking and unique movie experience. Takashi Miike has once again proven himself to be a master of the genre, and I look forward to seeing more of his films.

I sought out this film for one reason--Al Adamson. While he may not be the best director of all time, he has certainly made some entertaining films. This one was no exception. It was bad, but in a good way, reminiscent of some of his earlier, schlocky movies. As bad movie fans, we thoroughly enjoyed watching it.

At first, I was wary about watching this film because the title "Naughty Stewardesses" seemed a bit risque. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it wasn't pornographic, but rather a playful and entertaining movie. The first 10 minutes had some suggestive scenes, but the script underwent many changes, and for much of the film, there wasn't any titillation at all. Instead, we were treated to a surprising plot that came out of nowhere and kept us on the edge of our seats!

I was particularly impressed by the acting. For example, the 71-year-old actor in some of the love scenes was fantastic--he looked great for his age, and his performance was both charming and captivating. The final 20 minutes of the film became quite violent, with the same actor turning into a Rambo-like figure. Although it seemed a bit strange at first, it ultimately added to the film's entertainment value.

Overall, this is a movie that I would highly recommend. It's not your typical blockbuster, but it's certainly entertaining, sexy, and engaging. With such a crazy title like "Naughty Stewardesses," it's hard not to be intrigued.

Gillian Anderson is a confident, ambitious, career woman who meets working class charmer Danny Dyer for a night of excitement. After a minor mishap in the countryside, they encounter some trouble. Once recovered, and after a chance encounter with one of the trespassers, they contemplate seeking revenge...

I found "Straightheads" to be exhilarating. Intense, thrilling, bold, and impactful. If I didn't find the term overused, I would describe "Straightheads" as a cult classic. Clearly, it's the kind of film that would have had a cult following if released independently during the innovative days of the 1980's. Honestly, I'm thrilled "Straightheads" managed a cinema release.

I am not a prude, and I enjoy sex and violence in movies, as long as they are combined with a movie that a) has an engaging plotline or b) has captivating character development or c) ideally, both. "Straightheads" delivered both. The plot and characters evolved organically, and even the unresolved aspects added to the story's intrigue. Regrettably, the film ended too soon, clocking in at just 80 minutes.

It was a shame, because there was potential for a thought-provoking film here, and an especially noteworthy turn in the plot in the final third. How seldom do I say this, but it could have been even better if given more attention. Such a shame. I truly appreciate Gillian Anderson and Danny Dyer; they just needed a better platform with this film. She, especially, is highly underrated and still incredibly attractive.

I confess--Emma, in my opinion, is a remarkable novel that brings joy to its readers. Jane Austen has truly outdone herself in this masterpiece.

Comparing it to the Gwyneth Paltrow version is natural--it certainly captures the humor and spirit of the book, making it a delight to watch.

Kate Berkinsale, who previously played Flora Poste in Cold Comfort Farm, is a perfect fit for Emma with her wit and charm. Raymond Coulthard adds a touch of elegance as Frank Churchill. The production is stunning, and the interiors are tastefully designed.
While there are some areas to improve, the overall film is a fantastic adaptation of the beloved novel.
Firstly, Mark Strong's portrayal as Mr. Knightley is slightly different from what we'd expect. However, he still delivers a solid performance and brings his unique touch to the character.
Secondly, the length of the film could have been longer to fully capture the essence of the novel. Nevertheless, it delivers an engaging and entertaining experience.
Lastly, the adaptation is commendable. Andrew Davies has done an excellent job of preserving the essence of Austen's dialogue, making the film an enjoyable watch.
Overall, this adaptation is a must-watch for any Jane Austen fan. It perfectly captures the humor, spirit, and essence of the beloved novel.

A great idea, brilliantly executed. While that could describe many of the SciFi channel's movies, it definitely applies here. I love movies where a good back story is slowly revealed, and I like action movies, and I love all of the main actors, so this was a fantastic movie. The acting, writing, and directing by Bill Platt were all top-notch.

Another review rightly pointed out that knowing where you're going is essential to getting there. This movie does that and more. It's put together in such a seamless way that you can't help but be impressed with the second draft (and every other draft) of the script. Every scene is necessary and flows smoothly into the next, creating a cohesive and engaging narrative.

This movie also has a talent for explaining just the right amount of details, keeping the audience engaged and curious. The fights are exciting and well-choreographed, with no early abortions or conveniently placed "toxic adhesive" to be found. The final battle is thrilling and satisfying, with no laughable computer-revealed "plot" to detract from it.

If you are a fan of Shiri Appleby, watch this movie to see her shine. She delivers an excellent performance, breaking out of her "Roswell" persona and making for a great tough chick throughout the movie. John De Lancie also delivers a fantastic performance, bringing his unique charm to the character he plays.

In all, I gave this movie a 10/10 rating. It's a must-watch for any sci-fi fan.

I highly recommend watching this movie if you're a fan of the classics like Tom Wopat, John Schneider, Catherine Bach, Sorrell Booke, James Best, Denver Pyle, Sonny Shroyer, and Ben Jones! It's a great continuation that keeps the spirit of the original series alive. I enjoyed seeing Bo and Luke start the movie by running moonshine for Jesse, just like in the early days of the show. The movie features imaginative characters and unexpected situations that add a fresh twist to the story.

In this modern adaptation, Uncle Jesse is portrayed as a creative entrepreneur, and his moonshine-making comes across as a fun and quirky aspect of his character. The inclusion of Boss Hogg and Rosco, who were thought to be deceased, adds a magical touch to the story.

If you're looking for authentic Dukes of Hazzard experiences, I recommend watching the reunion and Dukes of Hazzard in Hollywood movies, which also star the original cast. This more recent movie, however, brings a new and entertaining perspective to the beloved franchise. I appreciate the effort to create a movie that respects the original series while offering something novel and exciting for both new and old fans alike.

I'm amazed by the people who made this film and put so much effort into it. I'm even more impressed by those who watched it and felt satisfied after spending 88 minutes enjoying a creative and thought-provoking experience like this movie.

First of all, the casting is fantastic, and the actors deliver their lines with authenticity and charm. The gore is definitely a highlight, but it's not as shocking as you might think, given the compelling performances and storyline.
If you enjoy the following:

- exceptional acting (the entire cast delivers outstanding performances. I've never witnessed this level of talent before).

- a captivating plot (this movie has a unique and surprising narrative that will keep you engaged).

- a thematic and thought-provoking experience (there's so much to learn from this film, from the horrors that can haunt us in our sleep to the complexities of the human psyche).

- an impressive soundtrack (the music enhances the overall experience, adding depth and nuance to each scene).

- beautiful scenery (the movie's stunning cinematography is a delight to watch, from the real-life rocks to the carefully crafted sets).

This movie is for you. Positive comments: the movie features interesting cinematography, particularly during the gore scenes, which are both terrifying and captivating. The gore effects are incredibly realistic, and the intestines scene is a classic. I couldn't agree more that disembowelment solves the fake accent problem.
