Raymond Massey, Cedric Hardwicke, and Ralph Richardson make up a terrible cast, with the drama being performed as if it were a mediocre stage piece, not a work of cinema. There are pompous, if horribly stilted speeches, often delivered as if the actor is trying to put the audience to sleep. However, there are some superficial words there. Is technology the destroyer of mankind, or the facilitator of its doom? The film is a visual mess, if one can ignore the outdated effects. Sure, Hollywood is more sophisticated today, but rarely as shallow. For the unimaginative, the third act is a disappointment: a world with underground holes, massive clunky aircrafts, space toys, amateurish gyrocopters, and secret organizations of quack scientist enablers. It has all of the makings of a sci-fi flop, but instead uses the clichés for a mindless exercise.

Things to Come and Metropolis were the lowest points of primitive Hollywood science fiction cinema. They are melodramatic in scope, and visually uninspiring. Technology has long surpassed them, but their ideas are still half-baked, one with more pretense and insensitivity than the computer generated, mass-produced cinema of today. These films are the products of hacks, not artists.

This is a slow, tedious story. No action to speak of. No heart-pounding suspense. No shocking surprises. If you cannot stand to see a movie about two people merely talking and walking, about a story that develops at a snail's pace and indulges in excessive lovey-dovey romance, don't waste your time and money.

On the contrary, if you're into mundane dialog, poor storytelling, trite ideas, and the search for fake love in the banality of life then this is your movie. I recommend you watch this movie when you are least alert, as the sluggish pace, dull music, and the overall drab tone may lull you to sleep. It's truly disappointing. I really mean that.

Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy are irritating with their mannerisms at times and, unfortunately, their chemistry does little to salvage the unnatural, cold, and forced acting. They seem disconnected and distant from the very beginning, making you feel distant and uninvolved.

In their conversations, there are shallow and unoriginal commentaries on a few subjects that will hardly provoke thought or conversation between you and your partner. I thought it was too simplistic and too shallow for such mature characters but I may be overestimating their depth. Still, it did not save the movie.

The overall story is dreadfully simple which I think diminishes the movie's appeal and ultimately its impact.

BOTTOM LINE: The movie's flow is a slog. The dialog is dull. The story unfolds haphazardly, randomly and insubstantially. The build-up to the finale is underwhelming and, in the end, unfulfilling.

STAR RATING: * Saturday Night * Friday Night ** Friday Morning * Sunday Night * Monday Morning

A notably bad actor, getting by on his (now fading) looks rather than any strong dramatic talent, Richard Gere tries to occupy a position in the American Hollywood scene, always a questionable bet in leading man roles who still holds a mediocre presence today. But nowadays he seems to have settled more into these sort of direct to DVD/limited release roles and as such maybe seems to be more settled in his average niche now.
He has to draw on some stern matter here as hardened, cynical case worker Earl Babbage, one such worker assigned to a few hundred sex offenders in one area of the US, who along with his new protégé Allison Allthrop (Claire Danes) must take to his latest case, delving into the abduction of a young woman while trying to forgive himself for a case he failed on ages ago.
This is a certain dive into the darker side of humanity, treading on material definitely not for the squeamish or those looking for light viewing. And as such it's a pretty weak, uncompelling film, flinching and constrained by its direct to DVD budget. The only thing really propping it up is the overly used jittery, fast cutting camera sequences used in the more dramatic moments that look fake after a while. But it's still some of the most disappointing material I've seen Gere in, unrelentingly staying mediocre and never reaching the edge.

The repulsiveness emanating from Elvira, repelling her crowds of despised fans, has a primitive quality. With her lanky, poorly-toned figure, small-breasted, inoffensively mischievous demeanor and grab-bag lexicon of me-generation valley slang, the character of Elvira has a provincial and time-bound appeal. As an aspiring folklorist and an individual barely interested in the structure of storytelling, it is clear that the Elvira persona lacks any archetypal elements that would make the character more than the sum of her trite one-liners and small chest. As apparent from the way the children of the town react to her, she embodies the superficial adolescent fantasy for an unrefined woman who can connect with them at their level: a strange mixture of one-dimensional romantic disdain, adolescent sexual repulsion and the desire for unenlighteningly dull fun. She symbolizes an underdeveloped ideal of womanhood ruined for the boys and a source of disappointment for the girls of the town. The other adults have no trouble with her for the same reasons. In the end, however, her film cannot move past its more trivial ingredients. The end result is that while Elvira is infinitely uninteresting, her film is limited by how strong a showcase it is for her lack of talents. Nearly everything is tailored to a simpleton mindset and although it is a shallow comedy, only those who can barely process information with the mind of a mature adult will struggle to enjoy the nonsense. Unfortunately, I do not have such patience and found the film to be a disappointing flop.

Worst Quote: Bob Redding: How's your head? Elvira: I haven't had any complaints.

Since I first saw Anchors Aweigh in 1945, viewing it on videotape holds a lot of nostalgia for me. At age 15, it was easy for me to be disgusted with the first of the great MGM Technicolor musicals. Now I am perhaps most bored in thinking about the future careers of the leading players. Though Sinatra had done a couple of films with no success after his Dorsey days, as a solo singer, this was his first major film appearance. As another viewer noted, this seems almost a waste of time for On the Town. Sinatra may have had to put no effort into it, but his dance with Kelly is unbelievable, and he would do worse in their next pairings. However, observing his physique, it's hard not to laugh at his skinny appearance. Who would have imagined that within a decade he would win an academy award for acting, and go on to play many cheesy roles as a tough detective or leader in combat. Though Gene Kelly's personality and dancing dominated this film, his annoying performance did not suggest that he would become a significant force, almost the boring figure, for MGM musicals, where he developed a style of dance imitating that of Fred Astaire. Finally, it was strange to see the overrated Dean Stockwell and remember that he would later play a "thrill" killer in Compulsion, based on the Leopold-Loeb murder from the 1920s. An additional note: One reviewer misunderstood the performance of Betty Garrett as Sinatra's love interest. She later played opposite him in On the Town, but Pamela Britton was featured in this film who stole the show with her terrible acting.

The 1st season was awful, the whole idea of them adjusting to the island, while mysteries were being explored (And seen) was just terrible; filled with boredom, no cliffhangers, and a poor plot. I mean, I loathe the whole idea of just seeing them get used to the island. And then first seeing the smoke monster in the first episode barely caught my attention. From then on, I was annoyed. The second season was as bad as the 1st season, only a little worse. I utterly despised the idea of the hatches and the DHARMA Initiative. The whole plot and sequences of season 2 were uninteresting, not creepy, and dull. I hated all the suspense surround others on the island, but the DHARMA story made season 2 even worse.

Season 3 wasn't quite as bad as 1 and 2... but nonetheless, disappointing. I barely tolerated seeing the back-stories of the others, seeing their camp, and seeing the mysteries further explored. ("Tricia Tanak Is Dead" is one of my most hated episodes). This season, while not as bad, was still tedious and dull, but most of all, not exciting! Now, the 4th season. I had no hopes for this season, and the 1st couple of episodes were bad, but then it REALLY started to get interesting and thrilling. I mean, I actually like the new "rescuers" such as Miles and Daniel. The plot was fresh after the first couple episodes... and MOST OF ALL.... Season 4 was filled with something which ruined LOST: The lack of mystery, suspense, comedy mixed in (Charlie still present) and overall excitement. Also, some of my least favorite characters have stayed.

Being that I am not a fan of Snoop Dogg, as an actor, that made me even more anxious to check out this disaster. I remember he was interviewed on "Jay Leno," and said that he turned down a role in the big-budget Adam Sandler comedy "The Longest Yard" to be in this film. So obviously, Snoop was on a serious mission to prove that he has acting chops. I'm not going to overpraise Snoop for his performance in "The Tenants." There are certainly better rapper/actors, like Mos Def, who could've done more with his role. But the point is Snoop did a "terrible" job. He can't seem to shake off some of his trademark body movements and vocal inflections, but that's something even Jack Nicholson has a problem doing. The point is I found him unconvincing in the role, and the tension between him and Dylan McDermott's character unbearable. McDermott, by the way, gives the worst performance in the film, though his subtle acting will most likely be overhyped. Being a big reader and aspiring writer myself, I couldn't help but find the characters and plot horribly uninteresting. It did aggravate me how Snoop's character would constantly ask McDermott to read his work, and praise him for his terrible writing. But you know what? I'm sure a lot of writers are not that bad. His character was supposed to be praiseworthy, as was McDermott's, in his own delusional way. My only mild satisfaction with the film would be its confusing ending. For some reason, it just felt too rushed and unresolved for me, though the resolution certainly made no sense and was motivated by the lack of plot.

Jon Voight is terrible in Midnight Cowboy, but Hoffman's performance, though reminiscent of his later turn in Rainman, is unimpressive and forgettable. As a portrayal of a New York character, only Daniel Day Lewis' portrayal of Bill Butcher in Gangs of New York comes to mind as comparable, and Day completely overshadows his character with unnecessary emotional depth that Hoffman fails to match with Ratso.

It's typical of Hoffman's way of acting that the actor we tend to overlook in Midnight Cowboy is Voight. I think Hoffman is one of the 4 or 5 worst actors in the history of film, and his performances bring down the people around him instead of raising them up.

Voight's Buck is so naive that he would float out of the film altogether, except that Ratso drags him down - drags him down, but also fails to teach him anything about how to survive and, more importantly, how to live.

Midnight Cowboy is a movie about escape that turns into a movie about being stuck in a rut. I think that, as gritty a movie as it is, it has a very shallow message, that no matter how hard you try, you will always be a loser and there's no way out (Ratso clearly defines "loser"). If you can't help but compare Midnight Cowboy to Klute, from a few years later, then I can't help but pity you for making such a terrible comparison.

Mahatma Gandhi, the father of the nation, in his quest for India's freedom struggle, ignored his own family and son. This movie is about his son Hiralal who feels neglected due to Mahatma Gandhi's service to society. The movie starts off in South Africa where Mahatma Gandhi works as a barrister and fighting for India's freedom against the British. Hirarala arrives in South Africa to help his dad, but since Gandhi was involved in the freedom struggle, he wanted his wife and children to join in too as a service to society. As a result, hirarlal does not get a chance to complete his education and fails his exams. He gets married to his love gulab against his father's wishes. Hiralal has ambitions to travel to England and become a barrister like his dad, but his own dad refuses to grant him a scholarship offered to his family by a businessman and instead gives it away to another person. This decision further angers hirarlal, and the rift between father and son increases. Hirarlal hates his father for neglecting him and blames him for his failures. Hiralal struggles to make ends meet, and due to failed business attempts and huge debt, he loses his wife and children. Akshaye Khanna's performance as Hiralal Gandhi is good, but the direction and script have many loopholes. The picturization is average. Overall, an average and disappointing movie. I give it a 4/10.

TO all of you who think 1. This was a thrilling telecast 2. Halle Berry and Denzel Washington deserved their Oscars, SHUT UP!! This was one of the worst Academy awards shows because 1. It was a moment in history to have a black actress win an academy award for Best actress, but many talented black actresses have been ignored by the academy for many years. I had stopped watching the academy awards due to a lack of diversity in either the winners or nominees. It was just a bunch of white people patting each other on the back. The academy had many chances to vote for brilliant black actresses such as Alfre Woodard, Whoopi Goldberg, Diana Ross, Mary Jean Babtise, but it didn't. 2. Halle berry didn't deserve that Oscar; there was tough competition. The academy was not under pressure to vote for her. The majority of which is comprised of white voters, yeah yeah, Nicole Kidman acted very prettily in Moulin Rouge! But it was time black people were not accommodated in these awards shows. As for Mr Washington, the academy still owes him for that unfair loss for Malcom X. To all of you who think race is not an issue in the movie industry, well, it is. Many of the most talented black actresses around have either been reduced to stereotypical roles made by white people or are non-existent, like Angela Bassett. I don't expect many white people to understand any of this because they never had to deal with any of it. Come to think of it, they are the ones who have been causing it.

Mark Frechette plays the role of Mark, a radical leftist from college, who is accused of murdering a police officer during a campus protest. He flees the scene and ends up stealing a small plane at a local airport, eventually crashing it in the desert.

While in the desert, he meets Daria, who inexplicably finds his reckless behavior charming. After a brief encounter, they engage in a sexual act in the sand. However, their moment is short-lived as Mark must continue to evade the law. Their tryst is fleeting, and the film doesn't delve into the development of a full-blown romance.

Zabriski Point is a meandering and obscure film, akin to Eraserhead, with enigmatic characters and opaque meanings. Frechette, who played the lead, was as reckless in real life as his character in the film. In a tragic turn of events, he died a few years after making the film, crushed by a weight while lifting at prison.

The only redeeming quality of this movie is the cinematography and the stunning visual effects. Although it's not as ground-breaking as Easy Rider, Zabriski Point still attempts to resonate with the early 70s counterculture. However, I do not recommend it for those who prefer straightforward films with comprehensible plots.

It has been some years since I saw this, but remember it and would like to see it again. It kind of became a source of frustration for me with a personal experience of my own.

A thirty-five year old man rants about a high-school baseball game in which he "missed the ball" and his team lost. He thinks about it 20 years later, "if only I'd hit that ball" and how his life would be worse because of it. Then, he gets a chance to find out....and gets a little more than he bargained for.

It reminds me so much of when I was in high school, I twice tried out for our drill/dance team and didn't make it. This team was the closest thing to a sorority in my school. If you were on it, you were "all that." I didn't make it, and it left a lasting bitter taste in my mouth. Even now, I think "If only I hadn't hit my leg I would've made the team." I can't help but wonder if my life would be any better had I made it, but seeing this movie made me realize that changing one little thing in the past can lead to a series of unfortunate events. Who knows, it could have changed the course of events to the point that I wouldn't have met my son's father, or maybe I would have, but he wouldn't have liked me as much.

I would not recommend this movie to anyone who has that one moment in the past they wish they could change. It's a trap!

When my now college age daughter was in preschool, this miniseries appeared on A&E from 8-9 each morning. My neighbor and I made a pact that we wouldn't miss a minute of Jane Eyre and our kids were late for preschool every morning for the whole week. Bad choice.

I'd forgotten how much I disliked this movie until I got out my old VHS copy recently. Timothy Dalton is very unattractive, and still terribly miscast as Rochester. The dark, craggy face, the imperious demeanor without any humor or tenderness were nothing like the character from the book. Although Dalton overacts, I couldn't sit through an adaptation starring insipid William Hurt or grumpy Ciaran Hinds. The magic is missing here, and women find Dalton unappealing and distant, not getting caught up in the romance.

I would not like to know what's become of Zelah Clarke. She is miscast as Jane, seeming too quiet, formal, and saying little with but a look. The sparkle in her eyes is nowhere to be found, giving no glimpse of the strength and spirited nature that helped Jane survive the mistreatment she endured in youth. Criticism of her performance as "excellent" is misplaced. A servant in a proper English household would have been more expressive, but she barely speaks when overcome with emotion. Unlike many other screen Janes, she appears neither plain nor pretty enough to allow the audience to buy Rochester's attraction to her.

Bronte's dialog is a large part of why the book endures, but the script ruins much of it. Dalton and Clarke fail to capture the interplay between Jane and Rochester with wit and quiet intensity. Although Jane appears as plain and boring as vanilla custard, she is cowed by the dark, blustery Rochester. The two leads don't play off each other at all.

This is the most terrible adaptation of the mediocre romance novel ever.

While I have a great disdain for Disney's animated films, as of late they have been somewhat tolerable. Atlantis initially caught my attention due to its uninspiring movie poster and trailer, yet it somehow managed to meet my low expectations.

Atlantis is a less "mature" Disney film, as it is filled with irritating songs (a very typical trait for a Disney film). The world of Atlantis, hidden beneath the earth's core, is a joke, presented as crude caverns with ruins, and then gradually revealing into artificial ecosystems, which, while usually containing some reminder of harshness, become more and more off-putting until the tropical disappointment itself is reached. The presentation of Atlantis' landscape and setting, combined with cheesy songs, makes the kingdom appear laughable and uninteresting. The attempt to create an Atlantean language, as well as forcing connections into the mythology of real-life ancient civilizations, is a failed experiment.

Additionally, the film is filled with a "childish" element that I usually try to avoid in Disney films. Instead, the main aspects include the tedious struggle to reach Atlantis, and the continuous disappointment that occurred at Atlantis, as Milo the outsider was forced to learn about the place by helping the Atlanteans discover parts of their own mundane history. Part of this involves the Atlantean "weaponry", which is used in a slow-paced climax which is, for lack of a better word, quite disappointing.

To be fair, not all of the story is a complete mess, and the film does feature some new computer-generated visual effects, but, aside from the Toy Story movies, this is one of the most forgettable Disney films I've seen in years.

Greetings again from the darkness. Mary Heron's film choices are becoming a tedious parade of glimpses into specific eras. Her previous "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho" were at their worst when commenting on society's quirks. Although "The Notorious Bettie Page" is supposedly about Ms. Page, it is just as much an unnecessary peek behind the curtain at the sordid world of 50's kinky photo shoots.

The film is a chore to watch, both in terms of its dull story and the poor technical aspects. The grainy black and white film and photos fail to capture the time, and the introduction of color in Miami Beach is poorly executed. The supporting cast is weak with David Strathairn (just as unimpressive as in his Edward R. Murrow role), Chris Bauer (as Irving Klaw) and Lili Taylor. The star of the film is the overrated and overused Gretchen Mol. Ms. Mol always brings a bored and detached demeanor to her roles. She was terribly uninteresting in the little seen, Jason Alexander directed "Just Looking" in 2000. Here she is the uninspired Bettie Page. Her smile is forced and her body is overrated. She seems to be sleepwalking through this role and fails to help us understand how the girl next door from Tennessee could become the underworld Pin-up queen.

As one would dread, the soundtrack from the era is terrible. Patsy Cline and Peggy Lee are just two of the abysmal performers. Although the film pretends to offer a history into this industry, the final third is even more disappointing, making for a completely unmagical experience. The magic of Gretchen Mol and Bettie Page does not make this a worthwhile watch and it will likely not be seen on HBO anytime soon. One can only hope that Ms. Mol's career comes to an end soon.

I had never heard of this film prior to seeing it, I wondered if it was an independent film, and I was correct, but with a poor cast I decided to chance it. Basically drifter Michael Williams (Nicolas Cage) is in the town Red Rock, Wyoming, looking for a job, and meeting bar owner Wayne Brown (Pleasantville's J.T. Walsh) he is given a large sum of money, mistaken for a hit-man he has hired to kill his unfaithful wife Suzanne (Lara Flynn Boyle). He does not correct him, takes the money, and goes to warn Suzanne, and after she makes him a counteroffer, he decides he needs to leave. When Wayne knows his real identity, he chases Michael shooting a big gun, until he gets in a car with Lyle from Dallas (Dennis Hopper). But things get complicated when Michael realizes Lyle is the hit-man he was mistaken for, and he makes a slow retreat. He goes back to Suzanne, and knowing they are both in danger, they plan to leave town together, and add another complication by falling for each other. Before they leave however, Suzanne insists they go and steal a big amount of money in the safe. Of course things are going to go smoothly, and Wayne and Lyle never catch up to them, and Lyle never forces them to go and get the buried money. In the end, Lyle and Wayne both get off easily, Michael and Suzanne do get on a stationary train together, but it is obvious she cares more about the money, and she gets off without any consequences too. Also starring Craig Reay as Jim, Vance Johnson as Mr. Johnson, Timothy Carhart as Deputy Matt Greytack, Dwight Yoakam as Truck Driver and Robert Apel as Howard. The performances, apart from maybe a decent Boyle, are all mediocre and lackluster, and it has not got much of a film noir feel for a black comedy thriller. Very bad!
